name: Continuous Delivery & Automation
description: Practices that enable fast, repeatable, and low-risk delivery of changes to production.

subDimensions.name: Version Control & Trunk-Based Development
subDimensions.description: Using a single source of truth (version control) and short-lived branches or direct commits on trunk.
levels: Foundational: Teams are establishing consistent version control, sometimes using longer-lived branches with occasional merging considerations.
Improving: Code is largely in version control, with efforts to reduce merge duration and complexity.
Accelerating: Short-lived branches or trunk-based development are standard, with frequent merges that streamline integration.
Leading: Continuous merging and an always-releasable trunk, supported by automated checks that sustain high quality.

subDimensions.name: Continuous Integration & Test Automation
subDimensions.description: Automatically building and testing changes in a shared codebase.
levels: Foundational: Builds and tests incorporate some manual steps; initial automated checks are being introduced.
Improving: Unit tests are automated in a CI pipeline, and teams are working to increase coverage.
Accelerating: Comprehensive suites (unit, integration, security) run automatically, ensuring rapid feedback in CI.
Leading: Extensive automated tests with near-complete coverage, providing immediate quality insights and swift iteration.

subDimensions.name: Deployment Automation & Release Orchestration
subDimensions.description: Automating the process of packaging, delivering, and releasing software changes.
levels: Foundational: Deployments are primarily guided by manual instructions or scripts unique to each environment.
Improving: Teams use consistent scripting and partial automation, with some human oversight during releases.
Accelerating: Deployments are triggered via pipeline steps or push-button processes across environments.
Leading: Fully automated end-to-end delivery, enabling frequent, reliable releases with minimal overhead.

subDimensions.name: Database Change Management
subDimensions.description: Aligning schema changes with application changes, versioned and deployed automatically.
levels: Foundational: Database changes are performed with manual coordination, and teams are exploring structured versioning approaches.
Improving: Scripts for migrations exist with partial rollback strategies; consistency is being refined.
Accelerating: Automated, versioned migrations integrated into the CI/CD pipeline, ensuring predictable updates.
Leading: Zero-downtime migration and rollback/roll-forward options are in place, promoting seamless database updates.

name: Architecture & Infrastructure
description: Technical foundations that enable independent, small-batch changes while ensuring reliability and scalability.

subDimensions.name: Loosely Coupled Architecture
subDimensions.description: Ability for teams to make changes independently without tightly coupled dependencies.
levels: Foundational: Systems are primarily monolithic, and teams are discussing ways to isolate components.
Improving: Some modularisation or microservices are introduced, with ongoing work to reduce interdependencies.
Accelerating: Services are independently deployable, supported by clearly defined data contracts.
Leading: Fully decoupled architecture, allowing teams to deliver changes swiftly with minimal cross-team coordination.

subDimensions.name: Cloud & Infrastructure Automation
subDimensions.description: On-demand, self-service, flexible environments for building, testing, and releasing changes.
levels: Foundational: Servers are provisioned using some manual steps, with early exploration of cloud adoption.
Improving: Basic cloud resources and partial infrastructure-as-code are in place, reducing manual efforts.
Accelerating: Infrastructure-as-code is widely adopted, enabling dynamic environments in CI/CD pipelines.
Leading: Fully elastic, on-demand infrastructure with advanced automation practices (immutable infrastructure, GitOps, etc.).

subDimensions.name: Platform Engineering
subDimensions.description: Providing an internal platform that streamlines development and reduces cognitive load on teams.
levels: Foundational: Individual teams manage infrastructure independently, with growing interest in a unified platform approach.
Improving: Basic shared services exist, offering partial self-service functionality for developers.
Accelerating: The platform is treated as a product, providing robust self-service capabilities to multiple teams.
Leading: A fully evolved internal developer platform, continuously improved through user feedback and iteration.

name: Lean Product Management & Process
description: Planning and delivery practices focused on rapid feedback, small batches, and limiting work in process.

subDimensions.name: Working in Small Batches & Limiting WIP
subDimensions.description: Delivering value in small, frequent increments and minimising parallel work.
levels: Foundational: Teams plan for larger releases with room to explore smaller batch sizes moving forward.
Improving: Early adoption of smaller user stories, gradually reducing batch size in releases.
Accelerating: A systematic approach to limiting work in progress, enabling frequent small-batch delivery cycles.
Leading: Continuous flow with minimal context switching and near real-time feedback, optimising throughput.

subDimensions.name: User-Centric & Hypothesis-Driven Development
subDimensions.description: Rapidly gathering user feedback and iterating based on real-world outcomes.
levels: Foundational: Teams primarily follow top-down feature direction, with increasing focus on user validation.
Improving: Some user research and feedback loops are in place, gradually accelerating response times.
Accelerating: Frequent experiments, such as A/B tests or user studies, guide decisions through data insights.
Leading: A culture of continuous experimentation at scale, with real-time analytics informing product evolution.

subDimensions.name: Stable, Prioritised Backlog
subDimensions.description: Maintaining clear, consistently prioritised work with stable objectives and minimal churn.
levels: Foundational: Teams experience shifting priorities and are establishing consistent backlog structures.
Improving: Basic backlog management is practiced, with ongoing efforts to reduce unplanned changes.
Accelerating: Short- and mid-term priorities are clearly set, limiting disruptions and promoting smoother delivery.
Leading: A well-groomed, stable roadmap aligned with strategic goals, enabling teams to plan effectively and confidently.

name: Observability & Resilience
description: Ensuring systems are measurable, monitored, and capable of rapid recovery from potential issues.

subDimensions.name: Monitoring & Alerting
subDimensions.description: Collecting telemetry (logs, metrics, traces) with actionable alerts for system health.
levels: Foundational: Basic monitoring is in place, and teams are refining approaches to address incidents proactively.
Improving: Centralised logging and dashboards provide more thorough visibility, while teams refine alert quality.
Accelerating: A unified observability platform correlates traces, metrics, and logs for deeper insights.
Leading: Proactive anomaly detection with SLO-based alerts, leveraging real-time data to drive continuous improvement.

subDimensions.name: Failure Recovery & Incident Response
subDimensions.description: How quickly a team detects and restores service after an incident.
levels: Foundational: Issues are addressed as they emerge, with incident response practices evolving.
Improving: On-call rotations and structured post-incident reviews are introduced to enhance response consistency.
Accelerating: Coordinated incident management, real-time collaboration, and systematic retrospectives strengthen recovery.
Leading: Automated rollback or restore, supported by blameless retrospectives that lead to significant resilience gains.

subDimensions.name: Chaos Engineering / Proactive Resilience
subDimensions.description: Introducing controlled experiments to validate system resilience and enhance fault tolerance.
levels: Foundational: Teams rely on existing tests and are beginning to explore proactive resilience strategies.
Improving: Occasional exercises (e.g. ‘game days’) to examine specific failure scenarios and refine responses.
Accelerating: Regular chaos experiments integrated into pipelines, with systematic learning from injected failures.
Leading: Resilience is integral to the culture; continuous exploration shapes architectural and operational decisions.

name: Security & Compliance
description: Incorporating security throughout the software lifecycle to protect against threats without slowing delivery.

subDimensions.name: Shift-Left Security
subDimensions.description: Including security checks and practices early in development.
levels: Foundational: Security considerations are introduced as teams review code or features, with further shifts planned.
Improving: Automated security checks are partially integrated into pipelines, expanding to cover more scenarios.
Accelerating: Security scanning is fully embedded in CI/CD, providing frequent validation and feedback.
Leading: Policies are codified and risk assessments automated, creating a continually improving security posture.

subDimensions.name: Secure Software Supply Chain
subDimensions.description: Safeguarding dependencies and ensuring code integrity from development through release.
levels: Foundational: Teams begin tracking dependencies and addressing security considerations as they arise.
Improving: Known vulnerabilities are scanned regularly, with enforcement policies in development.
Accelerating: Dependency monitoring is enforced by validated processes that guard against security issues.
Leading: A thorough, end-to-end supply chain approach that prevents tampering and ensures trusted releases.

subDimensions.name: Compliance Automation
subDimensions.description: Automatically verifying adherence to required standards (audit logs, policy checks) within delivery pipelines.
levels: Foundational: Compliance is monitored via manual checklists, with opportunities for partial automation under review.
Improving: Some evidence is gathered automatically, and gating steps are being introduced in CI/CD.
Accelerating: Compliance checks are fully integrated, with policies defined as code for consistent enforcement.
Leading: Continuous audit readiness is embedded, making compliance a seamless part of daily delivery.

name: Culture & Leadership
description: Organisational environment, leadership style, and collaboration practices supporting continuous improvement and high performance.

subDimensions.name: Westrum Organisational Culture
subDimensions.description: A generative culture emphasising cooperation, open information sharing, and learning from experiences.
levels: Foundational: The organisation is working towards open communication, with efforts to learn from outcomes.
Improving: Processes are in place to encourage collaboration, moving beyond departmental boundaries.
Accelerating: Greater generative behaviours emerge; teams share risks, and insights flow freely.
Leading: A truly generative culture where all voices are heard, and learning from any setback is the norm.

subDimensions.name: Transformational Leadership
subDimensions.description: Leaders inspire, empower, and enable continuous improvement across the organisation.
levels: Foundational: Leaders are establishing supportive practices, exploring ways to grant teams more autonomy.
Improving: Teams receive growing empowerment through delegated decisions, with increasing trust from leadership.
Accelerating: Leaders actively remove obstacles, invest in growth, and celebrate learning from experimentation.
Leading: A clear transformational mindset permeates the organisation, rooted in psychological safety and continuous progress.

subDimensions.name: Team Autonomy & Empowerment
subDimensions.description: Providing teams with the freedom to choose tools, drive experiments, and deliver business value independently.
levels: Foundational: Teams are gaining additional decision-making capabilities and establishing local ownership.
Improving: Autonomy is growing, with teams selecting some methods and tools, supported by increased trust.
Accelerating: High levels of autonomy, with teams shaping their own processes and experiments to drive outcomes.
Leading: A fully empowered environment, aligned to clear strategic goals, where ownership and innovation thrive.
